_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Air Products and Chemicals, Inc.
Middletown, Ohio Hydrogen Facility

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

At this facility, we manufacture gaseous hydrogen.  Hydrogen, in the amounts handled by our facility exceeds the threshold quonatity set by the EPA.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Air Producvts manages the safety of the regulated process by meansof operating procedures, equipment testing and inspections, safety devices (e.g., alarms, shut downs, instrumentation, relief devices) inherent in the design of this facility and other controls and systems designed to prevent accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices and training of our personnel suppliment the inherent safe design of the plant.

Our emergency repsonse program is bades on OSHA's HAZWOPER regulation.  The emergency resopnce plan includes procedures for the notification of local fire authorities and Hazardous Materials unit so that appropriate measures can be taken to control accidental releases.

This document has been prepared in  accordance with the EPA's Risk Management Plan regulation (40 CFR, Part 68).  The substances and processes considered during the preparation of this RMP and the scenarios described were selected based on criteria established in the regulation.

2.  The stationary source and regulated substance handled:

The primary purpose of this facility is to manufacture industrial gases, hydrogen is one of these gases.   Hydrogen is used by our customer in their manufacturing process.  Natural gas is received by our plant via pipeline and is used as our feedstock.  The feedstock is then compressed, mixed with steam and sent to the reformer furnace.  In the reformer furnace, the feedstock and steam are heated in the presence of a catalyst to approximately 1500 degrees F, where the chemical reaction takes place that converts the mixture into hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and carbon dioxid

e.  The pure hydrogen is then delivered to the customer via pipleline.  Backup is provided by a 20,000 gallon liquid hydrogen tank and gaseous hydrogen storage tubes.  The regulated process at this facility is the hydrogen production (reformer) plant and backup systems.

Hydrogen is the only regulated susbstance located at this facility in an amount exceeding threshold quantities.  The combined maximum amount of hydrogen and hydrogen containing flammable mixtures at this facility is 16,000 pounds.

3.  The genereal accidetal release prevention program and specific prevention steps:

The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Plan, andOSHA"s Process Safety Management (PSM) regualtion.  This facility was designed and constructed to comply with applicable state and industry codes.

4. Five-year accident history:

This facility came on line in September of 1967.  In the last five years there have been no accidents involving, or the accidental release of, flammable gas that resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site; or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacutations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. The emergency response program:

The facilities emergency response program is based on OSHA's HAZWOPER standard.  At this site, employees are trained to recognize emergencies and to initiate emergency response from outside agencies.  The have been trained to OSHA's First Responder Awareness Level.  The employees receive annual refresher training in their role in case of emergency.  Emergency response activites have been coordinated with the Middletown Fire Department for fires relating to the flammable process.  Periodic drills are conducted to review the effectivness of our emergency procedures.

6.  Planned changes to improve safety:

This facility was constructed in 1966.  The facility resolves recommendations from PHA's and Incident Investigation
s, in a timely manner, some of which may result in modifications to the plant design and operating procedures.
